questions.question_text:
Heather, a computer forensics investigator, is assisting a group of investigators working on a large computer fraud case involving over 20 people. These 20 people, working in different offices, allegedly siphoned off money from many different client accounts. Heather responsibility is to find out how the accused people communicated between each other. She has searched their email and their computers and has not found any useful evidence. Heather then finds some possibly useful evidence under the desk of one of the accused.
In an envelope she finds a piece of plastic with numerous holes cut out of it. Heather then finds the same exact piece of plastic with holes at many of the other accused peoples desks. Heather believes that the 20 people involved in the case were using a cipher to send secret messages in between each other. What type of cipher was used by the accused in this case?

Given the drive dimensions as follows and assuming a sector has 512 bytes, what is the capacity of the described hard drive?
22,164 cylinders/disk
80 heads/cylinder
63 sectors/track

comments.content:
Your multiplication is correct, but the amount of bytes in the result does NOT equal 57.19 GB.

57,193,758,720 bytes / 1024 (for KB) / 1024 (for MB) / 1024 (for GB) = 53.26 GB.

Answer A is correct.

choices.A: He should search in C:\Windows\System32\RECYCLED folder
choices.B: The Recycle Bin does not exist on the hard drive
choices.D: Only FAT system contains RECYCLED folder and not NTFS
choices.C: The files are hidden and he must use switch to view them

questions.question_text: A forensics investigator is searching the hard drive of a computer for files that were recently moved to the Recycle Bin. He searches for files in C:\RECYCLED using a command line tool but does not find anything. What is the reason for this?

discussion.content: I’m not sure about this one. NTFS has C:\RECYCLER or c;\$Recycle.Bin so…maybe D is could be correect
I guess the correct alternative is D

comments.content: Windows uses NTFS, Windows has a Recycled Folder or Recycle Bin. D is ruled out

choices.A: When the computer boots up, files are written to the computer rendering the data nclean
choices.C: When the computer boots up, data in the memory buffer is cleared which could destroy evidence
choices.D: Powering on a computer has no affect when needing to acquire digital evidence from it
choices.B: When the computer boots up, the system cache is cleared which could destroy evidence

discussion.content: @ Ripley52. I think they meant unclean.

comments.content: Removing cache is due to power down, not power up.

discussion.content: May I ask what is the meaning of nclean? I googled and can't find anything.

questions.question_text: Why should you never power on a computer that you need to acquire digital evidence from?
What is the slave device connected to the secondary IDE controller on a Linux OS referred to?

discussion.content: So, typically, a computer with IDE controller can accomodate 4 drives: /dev/hda (primary master), /dev/hdb (primary slave), /dev/hdc (secondary master), /dev/hdd (secondary slave).
